entry.title: I think my issue is that in order to successfully ...
entry.content:
I think my issue is that in order to successfully manage anything - dependencies, sales, umbrellas, smurfs etc - it helps a lot if they are *visible*.

With any abstraction, there is a price to be paid in that some class somewhere has to decide what concrete type of object to insert into that slot. That dependency DOES matter, because change can propagate along it. If a change to an entry in a Spring configuration file can cause my application to break - and we've all been there - then I maintain that there is a dependency there that we must be equally mindful of. I believe the curent wisdom is that, whenever possible, we should make our dependencies explicit for exactly these reasons.

And, just as Singleton isn't really about declaring things as "static", IoC isn't really about creating file-driven factories. We already have a pattern for object factories. It's called the "Factory pattern". IoC is a different pattern, that may involve factories just as Singleton may involve statics. But you can do IoC without factories quite easily.

Sticking type information in configuration files is not necessary. indeed, I'm arguing that the approach actually has disadvantages over writing them explicitly in your code, provided your design is good. but IoC won't transform a rigid, brittle code base into a robust, adaptible one. It might create that illusion, but the reality is that your dependencies are still there, and can still hurt you.

entry.title:
Jason,

As Seb says, if you need to output t...
entry.content:
Jason,

As Seb says, if you need to output the dependency graph it's trivially easy. Here's a little bit of code to do it on my blog:

http://mikehadlow.blogspot.com/2008/03/how-to-output-windsor-container.html

But in my experience of building application using IoC containers it's not something I've ever needed to do.

I think your issue is really with IoC (the big architectural thing) rather than IoC Containers (the small tool). You want to code concrete dependencies directly into your code, if I understand your argument correctly. This is what we all used to do. IoC was invented, a long time ago, to get around the limitations of this approach. IoC is fundamentally about code reuse; allowing you to don't-repeat-yourself. That DRY principle is one of, if not, the fundamental imperatives of programming. I think the problems that people have with IoC, is that it's a design pattern rather than something that's baked into the language. We would never argue that objects or functions are a bad thing (I hope) but they grew out of the same desire to allow code reuse.

Without IoC you cannot reuse code that co-ordinates or orchestrates lower level components, you cannot enforce the open-closed-principle and every time you take a high level component anywhere you are forced to drag along its dependencies. This is bad for design flexibility, it's disastrous if you are serious about unit testing.

Now if you're going to use IoC, which I think you must with any statically typed language, you can make your life a lot easier with an IoC container. IoC containers are essentially simple tools that resolve your dependencies for you, they should be more or less transparent to your application, but they're the icing on the cake of IoC and wholly dispensable. It just means you have to do more work if you don't have one, and who likes doing more work? Like any tool they are open to abuse, but that's true of almost everything in programming and no reason for not using them.

Mike

entry.title: Well, it's two-fold, really. Firstly my issue is w...
entry.content:
Well, it's two-fold, really. Firstly my issue is with IoC frameworks being used for something other than Inversion of Control, e.g., as factories.

And then I still have to dispute, having seen it done on dozens of projects, that IoC frameworks really do tend to lead to code that's easier to change. I repeat what I said earlier: how is it easier to change the type of a cponcrete class in a configuration file than it is in a source code file? I still need to retest and redeploy my software, either way, since both change scenarios could break my code. As long as I only need to make the change in one place, and as long as my internal design binds to the abstraction and not the implementation everywhere else, I am really struggling to see the difference.

I've also come from a background where we just wrote it in the code. And I've spent a lot of timer with all manner of IoC flora and fauna. And I have seen little or zero gain. Quite the reverse, oftentime, when the IoC container is used willy-nilly.

But then again, I don't have the proof either way. Does anyone have hard data on this problem?

entry.title:
Jason

I understand when you say that using ...
entry.content:
Jason

I understand when you say that using an IoC container + external configuration file can have double negative impact of making the code more difficult to follow with the IDE, no longer one can use debugging to step through object construction as this is handed over to the container.
The other issue, I believe, lies with the fact that we're moving away from compile time binding to runtime.

Regarding the external configuration:
- There are fluent APIs around allowing to wire components/services together therefore making dependencies clearer to trace (http://hammett.castleproject.org/?p=250) and compiled too in the assembly itself.

- I would like to point that the fact that IoC may use an external configuration resource does not automatically render IoC useless. Just have a look at the most trivial Web.Config or App.Config file in any sizeable configuration to see other dependencies your codebase may have at runtime that you cannot see at compile time (for http handlers/modules registration, asp.net providers registration, etc etc, the .net framework is littered with these things).

Daniel

entry.title: Well I am definitely a fan of IoC containers. I j...

Well I am definitely a fan of IoC containers. I just like the fact that, when writing a class, you don't have to think where you will be getting your dependencies from!

Without a container this process just becomes so much more tedious!

entry.title: Rasta is a framework for asp.net 2.0 that lets you...
entry.content:
Rasta is a framework for asp.net 2.0 that lets you write REST applications, with full support for content type negociation, URI mapping / rewriting, and preservation of the webforms where possible.

If you think about a webforms application, you're in a view-first environment, so mankind created MVP.

But because that was not very satisfactory, one said one day that the person in charge should be asked first, and then was born MVC. This is controller first.

Rasta takes a different approach, and puts forward the notion of resource first. Each Url can map to a resource, and a specific resource can be acted upon by many handlers. The dereferencing of a Url triggers one of those handlers that act upon your resource, and may do stuff with it.

Way after that, and completely independent from the handler, an entity may have been returned, and one of the codecs will be responsible to turn it into a representation that was requested, be it a custom mime type, a web page, an image, json, xml, etc.

So that's basically what Rasta is: A way to design resource-oriented website, and a complete separation of operations on a resource and it's eventual representation.

I will try and start blogging about it more in the next few weeks, but I still havent got the green light for the framework to be open-sourced yet, and i'm going through a v2 iteration right now to fix issues the first version had, so it's all a bit in limbo :)

entry.title:
Hi Sebastien,

IIS 7.0 has (once more) gotte...
entry.content:
Hi Sebastien,

IIS 7.0 has (once more) gotten hardened with respect to client input, with multiple measures to help guard against canonicalization attacks. Every such measure is a tradeoff between the freedom of the application to control it's own URL space, and protecting poorly written applications against current and future exploits by restricting input.

In this case, you are most likely running into the request filtering limit double-encoding feature, which by default rejects requests if their URLs are different on a second URL decode. I wouldnt recommend a normal app to disable this, but if you must turn it off, you can do it in the <requestFiltering> config section, allowDoubleEscaping attribute. The request filtering feature is responsible for most of the additional limitations on request input in IIS 7.0, icluding shorter default limits on querystring length and other request item lengths.

ASP.NET also continues to validate URLs to avoid canonicalization issues by running them through MapPath. This will reject URLs that contain special characters not allowed by the configuration system, or attempts to pass URLs that contain encoded characters.

If you are using ASP.NET APIs to rewrite urls, ASP.NET will apply this logic to those URLs again - for concern that an application could take a malicious string coming from the client and turn it into a URL that exploits a canonicalization vulnerability.

This obviously impacts applications that rely on these URLs, but in most cases this is a necessary evil in order to help defend countless other applications that may otherwise be vulnerable. In other cases you can turn it off :)

Hope this helps you out ...

Thanks,

Mike

entry.title: EF doesn't prevent you from doing anything, but it...
entry.content:
EF doesn't prevent you from doing anything, but it is communicated / targetted at providing reusability of your model across applications. I argue that it's less wasteful to have a model specific to your application and deal with synching data across applications than it is to suffer a common model and a sharing of one data source.

Within your application of course you should avoid duplication. But then again I'd also argue that your model should be internal to your app, and your clients should communicate through DTOs targetted at the operation at hand, and you have duplication there as well. And it's a good thing: it isolates your client against changes in your model, it defines a contract you can agree on and it sends around just the right amount of data needed to achieve whatever the client is trying to achieve, and nothing more.

Wasting CPU time copying data is less expensive tha wasting time with one model that ripples any changes across all applications sharing it.

The EF target is to have one model so you can reuse this and the business rules across applications and even across tiers. That's where I disagree, as I've seen the result of this approach and I don't know anyone who has been successful with it.

@joeyw - Mapping layers are not wasted cycles - they are important tenets in retaining loosely coupled system architecture!

This was the exact issue we had when we developed that app - the services were insisting on returning their own internal data types to the clients. I was pushing for DTOs if you remember, but that never happened and it made it really hard to write our client didn't it (e.g having to send back the right "parent IDs")!

I read this article several years ago - http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms954587.aspx - and have always tried to follow those principles and patterns contained within when designing my services. entry.title:

that is debatable. If you put a system...
entry.content:
Jon,

that is debatable. If you put a system under test, you'll fix bugs and induce code changes that will end up being tasks that are part of a new release. Writing post-mortem tests without issuing any new code won't add value and will just cause more issues.

The value in code-freezing and writing the tests afterwards is really low. Code without tests is your technical debt. You'll end up finding design issues when you put them under tests and won't be able to release any fixes for that, which in turn makes the whole suite of tests brittle.

So overall, if you're not going to do a new release, call it a service pack or a new version, writing post-mortem tests doesn't provide much benefit at all.

entry.title: That's where I have a problem. The idea behind tha...
entry.content:
That's where I have a problem. The idea behind that client lib is that you don't need any knowledge of the way controls work or the javascript involved, and it's completely decoupled from rasta itself.

I really think that decoupling the binding and the element, you end up with a much more approachable solution, and the client lib can be used on its own, without having to write javascript code.

As soon as you write javascript, you bind to the object model of the lib, which makes things like updating the code much harder.

And there's a final issue: if you require the libraries to be loaded, which they are only when the DOM is ready, inline scripts to attach behavior would block until they're executed. Otherwise, you need to hook up to a ready event, be it that it's provided by jquery or load or whatever... And that makes the decoupling either less decoupled.

entry.title: Why wouldn't the text/xml-script approach validate...
entry.content: Why wouldn't the text/xml-script approach validate as HTML5?

entry.title: HTML4 simply references content of script tags gen...
entry.content:
HTML4 simply references content of script tags genrating valid SGML CDATA, which will switch the parsing mode to check for [/ to delimit the end of the cdata block, so you end up having to escape with [![CDATA[ ]]]

HTML5 relaxes the cdata elements by allowing nearly anything within a [script] as long as it is not [/script, so you may well be right that in that case the xml-script element would be allowed, as an opaque block. However, the spec talks about both CDATA elements and CDATA sections, without implying if a CDATA element can indeed contain a CDATA section.

With HTML5 Xml however the problem is simple, you need a CDATA, as this is what the script tag implies. Xml parsing rules aren't compatible with the new definiton of CDATA sections from HTML5.

However, Xhtml 1.0 script tag is not defined as CDATA but as PCDATA. This is more restrictive as entities in that block will be resolved and you will need to either escape everything or, of course, enclose in a CDATA section.

Confusingly enough, whichever way you look at it, be int HTML4, SGML or XML serialziations of html, you are not allowed to put pure xml in there.

This is also why the proposed changes to add namespaced attributes for the future of Atlas is bogus for most of those serialziations, unless they are enclosed in CDATA and parsed in the DOM at a later stage using namespaces at that point.

entry.title: IIS 7.0 uses "precondtions" to determine which mod...
entry.content: IIS 7.0 uses "precondtions" to determine which modules are invoked for a request. If the request has a native handler, modules with the "managedHandler" precondition will not be invoked. This association occurs before the BeginRequest notification. So if you rewrite the URI during or after BeginRequest, the modules associated with the request will not change. This is why MVC sets system.webServer/handlers/runAllManagedModulesForAllRequests to true.

entry.title: The whole basic point of mocking out an object is ...
entry.content:
The whole basic point of mocking out an object is that you want an object that can be used as X, without it being X, so that if X fails your test still runs.

You can make explicit mocks, but that splits your test logic into multiple bits that have no clear relation. I much prefer a test that says "I will do X" and then says "Do X", with as few as possible extraneous logic as possible. I want it all to be in the *test* itself, not spread around. I despise the test fixture idea because it strips my test of clarity - even though it reduces code.

You are telling me to split the test and the mock being used by that test, to save about 30 characters of code? At the expense of clarity?

Are you serious?

entry.title: The point I am making is simply that the amount of...
entry.content:
The point I am making is simply that the amount of code required to write a test double is not that high. Depending on what you're trying to achieve in your tests, a mockign framework is not always necessary.

I am comparing character counts simply because the case has been made several times that mocking was supposedly saving you time. I question this.

Now that rhinomock has an AAA syntax and defaults to dynamic mocks, and moq is available, the problem is much reduced and i'm more comfortable with the use of those frameworks.

As for creating your mocks inside your test, if you provide a test double you should do it yourself to ensure default code paths execute successfully. Any other kind of tests will require you to implement or reimplement your mock with just enough functionality needed for yoru component to work.

Those test doubles are by definition more fragile which could lead to your tests being more brittle.

So you're telling me you recreate your objects and methods *in every test*?

Are you kidding?

Let's drop the attitude from the comments I don't find it much constructive.

entry.title: My take on what not to do: Calling your process ag...
entry.content:
My take on what not to do: Calling your process agile, without understanding what agile is.

I suggested to a team that we try agile, but no one, including myself really knew what it was. I knew you were supposed to break stuff up into iterations, and there usually is less up front requirements, but that's about it. No one else challeged me, or bothered to look into this more, and of course, how many developers like writing requirements, so anything that "promised" less requirements was seen as good.

So we basically ended up doing waterfall, but broke up our tasks into small enough pieces to fit into a 2 week iteration. We completly missed the customer feedback loop, failed to update our estimates based on project velocity, etc.

Needless to say, this process did not work. We are actually closer to an agile process now then we were in the past. An unfortunete by-product is that the word agile, and anything associated with it (i.e. TDD) is now Taboo.

I learned that agile is not a get rich quick scheme. Be sure to understand what agile is, and what you want to get out of it before going foward with it.

entry.title: I worked on one project and the team lead/architec...
entry.content:
I worked on one project and the team lead/architect absolutely refused to produce any diagrams (even on a whiteboard) because "Agile doesn't have artifacts." This made it very difficult to understand the business model.

The Agile projects I have been on have actually been more restrictive than the RUP, Waterfall, etc ones: you must work in pairs, you must do TDD, code should not contain any comments.

In addition, I have found that coming onto an agile project after it has been in progress for some time, more difficult than coming onto a RUP project. The Agile project has no documentation. Sure, there are stories, but there is no context for the stories. And it's very probable that the story is out of date because a later story changed or even removed that functionality. With RUP, the documents provide much more context which is very helpful when one isn't familiar with the problem domain. Sure they too are probably out of date, but they're still good to get the basic understanding.

On one Agile project with two week iterations, we'd usually define what we were to build by Wednesday or Thursday of the first week. A build with the functionality in it had to be provided to QA on Wednesday of the second week. That left about 5 days of actual development per iteration. Our stories were too large to fit in 5 days of coding so developers took shortcuts like crazy and produced some extremely bad code.

On my current Agile project, we developers have unit tests but, obviously, the unit tests don't verify that individual classes or modules work together. The business analysts write integration tests but the developers don't have access to them because of a shortage of licenses. Us developers get demerits if we introduce bugs but we have no way of double-checking before we commit our code. This has made some of our developers very reluctant to do any refactoring.

On another Agile project, we were concurrently working on three iterations: a two week, a monthly, and a quarterly. Usually the people working on the quarterly iteration only worked on that iteration while the other developers worked on multiple iterations. We were very reluctant to do any refactoring because of possible merge problems.

I have more horror stories. Having worked on RUP and Agile projects, I prefer RUP. They tend to be less screwed up at the process level and developers have a better idea what they're building and why (and thus can contribute rather than just being code monkeys).

entry.title: Using "we're agile" as a euphemism for "we're crap...
entry.content:
Using "we're agile" as a euphemism for "we're crap":

* Let's not write unit-tests (before or after) because it's well known that developers cannot test their own output (read: "we don't want to think too hard about what we're building or why, because that would involve effort"). We have a tester! Surely he will just tell us what's broken; his mental powers of communication should be adequate to the task of reading our minds (or at least the 1tonne write-once/read-never specification that's being written)

* We're a team, but we all have our individual tasks to work on and when we finish we don't take our head out the sand to see whether another team-member needs help to meet the team's deadlines - "Well, _I_ finished on time, _those_ guys were late!"

* The business/stakeholders have such low expectations, and have got so much into the habit of accepting "but we're working on the innards, not the UI at the moment - you can't see that stuff", that they don't ask for things any more, but still complain when the project is late but they don't really understand why. People who want a project but don't set goals, don't get a project that achieves any goals.

* Retrospectives? What do we need to learn from our mistakes for? Wait wait, mistakes? We don't want to talk about those, especially not when other people might hear about them! Definition of insanity - doing the same old thing in the same old way and expecting a different result.

* Geographically distributed "agile" without strong leadership (as distinct from "management") DOES NOT WORK (here, at any rate).

* Let's not put the web-developers on the website project; let's put the infrastructure guys on that, and watch them use font tags and style attributes despite being told that this application must be skinnable via CSS. Let's make the competent people not work on the system that is supposed to save the company; let's glue them to the legacy system and not give them the resources they ask for.

* Documentation? Sure, we'll write stuff in a wiki, but it's only useful when people READ IT.

* Let's not have a backlog, and, you know what? Let's not have tasks at all! We'll just say "we're writing code!" whenever we're asked about what we're working on - that way, we can be telling the truth! Of course, we're writing things like validation frameworks (because the world doesn't have enough of those) instead of things that, you know, the business can market and sell.

* Let's have a manager that micro-manages from a remote site instead of leads from the trenches. Delegation is for those pinko-liberal teams where we've heard whisperings of such voodoo as "independent thought" "initiative" and "innovation". No, it's the MS way or the highway in our well-tuned outfit; how would we recruit if we didn't write stuff that anyone off the street could pick up and work on? It's FINE to use copy/paste, because everyone knows that's simpler than that object-orientation stuff - those features ("inheritance", "interfaces", "separation of concerns" etc) are far too advanced to risk using.

Does the dailtywtf have a "wtf agile" category?

entry.title: I think you make some very good points Seb. The 4 ...
entry.content:
I think you make some very good points Seb. The 4 principles that they have created are very easy to agree with (I agree with them, and have signed). As such they remind me a little of horoscopes, sufficiently loose to be easily seen as relevant, insufficiently detailed to be truly meaningful without liberal interpretation. What is well crafted to one person (data driven, anaemic, no concern for separation of concerns, rich client etc...) will not be to others (DDD, clear separation of concerns, rich model, etc...).

Who thinks that they don't steadily add value, no one I work with, yet I might see some of their efforts as leading to a ball of mud, and they might see mine as unnecessarily complex.

When it comes to communities of professionals being emphasised then I think your point about being involved in existing communities is very important. As you say the Alt.Net community has clearly been pushing at this space for a while, as have others. Why not engage from within these communities rather than seek to to create a new one?

As for productive partnerships vs. customer collaboration. Well if a customer collaboration doesn't end up meaning a partnership then it won't be productive IMO. And who out there was aiming for an unproductive collaboration? No one.

I think you are entirely correct in pointing to the need for wider engagement in organisations and emphasising the need to for the business context/need to be taken into account. These beautiful sentiments of the new manifesto will only be implementable if the paying customer is willing to recognise the need. This takes engagement with the business to show it the need, and to assist in its transformation. Also to recognise that this need will not always be present. We will never be a 'craft' in the kind of pastoral pastiche that is alluded to by this movement. The dialectic of history will not be seeing us return to 'crafts'. I can appreciate that we are in some senses closer to artists than engineers (arguably so are engineers). But 'craftsmanship' this is some post-Bob Dillon bullshit neo-folk bullshit. Nice sentiments, but not going to go anywhere. A profession might be reachable for, but even then this requires widespread recognition (usually in law) of professional bodies that choose to admit members and require standards of them. Quite frankly this is not going to happen, ever, period. The age of the profession itself can be seen to be passing with the growth in neo-liberalism and its twin technologies of audit and risk management. Professionals in any field have since the late 1970's been subjected to increasing levels of colonialisation from the hegemony of the large accounting companies. Even where the technologies of audit are seen to fail, from BCCI through Enron, to the current crisis from inappropriate securitisation, the response of governments and agencies is to call for greater levels of audit, and tighter risk management. All of which seeks to make redundant the traditional liberal technology of professions.

Anyway, this response to agree with you has turned into a rant, one which I hope you will forgive my posting underneath your excellent blog post. I am now starting to regret signing up to the manifesto.

entry.title:
Hi Sebastien,

I did sign the manifesto, and...
entry.content:
Hi Sebastien,

I did sign the manifesto, and I even played a very minor role in helping craft it. I am also somewhat involved in the ALT.NET community, the Ruby community and the Agile community.

(And this is all IMHO)

I agree with your questions about how this relates to the large organizational context of producing software that delivers value to a customer. In some ways, it doesn't. That's because how you deliver value in a 4-person shop differs quite a bit from a 40-person or 4000-person shop. However, how you /write/ the software should indeed be very similar.

We should be leaving the code better than how we found it. We should be writing test-first (or at least thinking from that perspective). We should be striving on doing the simplest thing that could possibly work, keeping our methods and classes small, and practicing things like the SOLID principles.

Further more, we should be rejecting the efforts of organizations who want to measure us on LOC per day or other such silly metrics.

Regarding the involvement in the ALT.NET community - I would say in fact that there has been some bridge efforts. I find that what the ALT.NET, Ruby, Agile and Software Craftsmanship communities want are very similar - quality software that delivers value to our customers. I have found the ALT.NET mailing list to not be a productive place to have those conversations as of late - in fact, my posting about a month ago detailing why and asking what people would want out of such a community lead to 3 responses - no of which brought on further discussion.

Regarding the objectives - I believe that the goal is to put a line in the sand of where a group of us believe software development should move towards. Not everyone agrees with it, but it has caused the conversation to start happening, which is worthwhile.

Finally - I also have taken objection to the movement of the craft community around it being targeted at smaller shops. I deal with a group that has ~50 developers in 8 teams. How I approach software development, management and the such is going to be different.

I'll have to catch up with the thread going on at the ALT.NET list, and perhaps that may give some more insight. While I'm not on that side of the pond, I'd be happy to chat more about what my view is.

entry.title: Let's put aside for a moment the emotional res...
entry.content:
Let's put aside for a moment the emotional responses: I think you're missing a number of point I made besides the dogma remark, which I admit was a little over the top and that I'll gladly apologize for.
As it stands today, serving XHTML as XML doesn't work, because of Internet Explorer, otherwise we would gladly use it. So what extensibility mechanism remains in XHTML today that would justify the X in XHTML as "extensible" rather than just a letter borrowed from XML (where it also stands for extensible)?
As you rightly point out, you can isolate the markup in a CDATA section or in a separate file. Well, we tried that before, it was called XML-Script (in the Atlas days) and it was almost universally hated. But clean it was.
Another solution you point out is basically class-embedded microformats. I personally object to that (but it's clearly just an opinion) because it's hijacking an existing attribute for something quite far from its intended design, and because it inevitably leads to markup within markup and to double or triple encoding problems (different kinds of encoding even). It's ugly, impractical and difficult to tool. Not even talking about perf.
As for pushing for better standards through the relevant channels and for pushing Internet Explorer to get their act together regarding XHTML (and other things), we are also absolutely doing that and please note that it's quite orthogonal to the question of what we can do today, with today's browsers.
So has tag soup won? Well, libraries such as Dojo certainly seem to think so, as they are quite happy to add non-namespaced custom attributes on regular HTML. Just ask Alex Russel what he thinks about XHTML... (not using an authority argument here, just pointing out that there are all sorts of opinions out there, including from people much smarter than I am).
We chose to go for a syntax that is a little closer to XML-compliance than that and that *works in all browsers*.
It should also be very clear that the declarative syntax is in no way the only way to use the features of 4.0. It is perfectly possible to use every single feature in 4.0 with 100% compliant markup and unobtrusive code. We actually spent quite some time ensuring that.
But for people who are not quite so intent on strict compliance and who prefer to get the job done in a very simple and expressive way (there are a few), they can.

entry.title:
Bertrand,
no amount of conversation is too much, ...
entry.content:
Bertrand,

no amount of conversation is too much, and thanks for responding.

As I've highlighted here, I don't mind so much the breakage of strict compliance, provided microsoft provides a valid DTD for those anal people that see validation as important. Nope, I'd be quite happy with that, provided such a DTD is crafted and can be implemented for those that want it.

Let's review the scenario you allege to: using unregistered extensions on HTML4.

I don't particularly like it, and prefer, like many, using the class attribute to achieve some if not all of those issues. As I've pointed out from my blog entry in august 2008, which highlights that the xml script proposal that was made also resulted in invalid content (I've put a link on the entry), it's however not doable for anything remotely complex.

Hence my proposal at the time to provide a different type of styling, based on a CSS-like syntax. Your blog contains such a proposal, except it's using the script tag instead, which breaks a bunch of scenarios. I do think there's value in one of those solutions long term.

But as you mention adding unknown attributes in html, yes I would much prefer such a solution from a compat perspective, the reason for this blog entry. It doesn't break the DOM, works across browsers with no compat issue, and doesn't break CSS selectors. It's not as good as externalizing those in a separate language, included through scripts or styles, but it's less bad than using xml namespaces.

I will ask you this: if you were to take one of those two routes, would you break as many scenarios as you would if you went the xhtml path?

The fact of the matter is that you wouldnt, and until xml namespaces in html is a solved problem, and DOM level 2 and xml namespace parsing works in IE, it is wishful thinking that xml namespaces will work for those people more interested in letting their resources be accessible by non-browser agents uderstand xml.

I do note however, emotions set aside, that comparing my argument to "people that want to get stuff done" is irresponsible as far as the web architecture and the state of html / xhtml is.

I do believe that this attitude is one of the main reasons for a lot of the pain inflicted on the world of web development by Microsoft and others, and coming to an entry criticizing your easy criticism of standard-based objections as being dogmatic to object that breaking the web is not important for "people trying to get things done" is irresponsible.

Microsoft has a responsibility not to impose an easy path for people to break the web further, because a lot of your consumers will never adopt anything beyond what you have published. By publishing something that breaks by default in more ways than any other option, you're accepting the fact that you're going to muddy the waters for XXX more years to the xhtml community.

You argue it's easy. I argue that simple is not easy, and the actions of your team will unleash millions of developers in the wrong direction.

Let's try and get this conversation and alternatives open in public, for discussion, with potential review by the html working group or / and the TAG. What do you say?

entry.title: I'm happy reviewing nay work that is done of c...
entry.content:
I'm happy reviewing nay work that is done of course.

I'd really prefer to have an open discussion, with several scenarios, and a side-by-side comparison of how many issues come with each, and get it reviewed by enough people to represent all viewpoints.

The main objective for any web-based technology should really be, when one try to help people get things done, to not break other people's scenarios, and xhtml definitly is one scenario I don't want to see broken.

entry.title: One of the problems with using OSS frameworks is t...
entry.content:
One of the problems with using OSS frameworks is that you need to evaluate that framework's suitability and long term viability. The more choices, the more time everyone has to spend choosing which one is the right choice, the more diluted the community, the more chance each solution has to fail due to lack of support.

I would rather the OSS community demand a level of quality and innovation before accepting new products as viable solutions. Sure it is nice when people give away stuff for free but if you've ever spent time browsing sites like sourceforge, freshmeat and codeplex they full of well-intentioned efforts to contribute, but the end result is often worthless and just adds to the noise.
Unfortunately the 80-20 rule has a significant effect here. It is often not that hard to produce a significant portion of the functions of many OSS frameworks and products, however, it is the testing, refinement and maturation of a product that takes a whole lot of time and effort. However, it is these mature products that make OSS a viable alternative, not the 101 half finished efforts.

entry.title: "if it was a different approach or a differen...
entry.content:
"if it was a different approach or a different problem, maybe. If it does the same as other REST frameworks, it's a waste of time and resources."

Sabastien, this doesn't sound like "waste" in the context of lean - it *sounds like* "a waste of time and resources". I believe some of the problem lies with the media you used to start your coversation - Twitter. Twitter doesn't let you establish much context to your comments with a 140 character limit. I've seen similar heated discussions start because of Twitter. So, a small measure of blame can lie with Twitter.

That said - any comment made about code written by anyone with such obvious talent as Nate (especially someone making their code publicly available for free) that uses "a waste of time and resources" in any context, lean or otherwise, is probably not going to make you any friends.

Finally, my two cents: I don't mind duplication and I'll explain why - it's not 100% duplication. Nate made different choices in architecture, design, and naming than any other solution available. Those differences are worth something - they show another viewpoint of the same problem. If enought of those viewpoints surface in the OSS community, it usually results in breakthroughs. The 5% or 10% that is unique in each solution can push people to totally new paradigms and solutions that are far more useful than any existing solution. So yes, Nate and others in the OSS community have very much contributed to a high percentage of software/solution duplication - just not 100% duplication. I find this valuable.

entry.title: @Jordan My understanding of lean has very much bee...
entry.content:
@Jordan
My understanding of lean has very much been around uncertainty limitation. When you approach a new problem, you have to limit the potential damage of taking on a new approach. Without this limitation, it becomes very risky to come up with your own.

The whole idea behind limiting risk is to make sure that you have a thorough understanding of what risk is involved, and what difficulties lie ahead, when you're going to implement your own.

As such, *pure duplication* is going to increase risk, and should be frown upon.

Now, once again, i've not talked about Nate's technical solution in either my original comments on twitter (they were related to the concept of "different approaches"), or in these comments, or my blog entry.

Nate's solution is a naive approach to the problem that fits his needs. Considering how little functionality is actually involved in that solution, I can't say that I would constitute what he released as waste. It's a practical solution to a practical problem. There's many areas that are not covered, because Nate didn't need them.

As such, and I'll repeat myself *again* on this, I am not criticizing Nate's framework, for it is fairly inconsequential to this conversation.

The point I tried to make, within the context of this conversation, has been that reimplementing your own way of doing things, when it is a risk big enough (and we've established that Nate's framework is too small to be considered a risk), should be avoided until such a time it is established that producing a custom solution is the only cost-effective and risk-effective way to solve the problem at hand.

I am very concious that everybody is focusing on this idea that my twitter messages, or this entry, is criticizing nate's "framework". It isn't. It was a response to the "nothign wrong with different approaches", and a followup to the long blog entry Nate felt he needed to post on his blog after our 4 twitter messages exchange.

I've given up on people understanding the difference between the context of the conversation and the trigger of the conversation that was a release of a "framework". It is very obvious that I have failed miserably, over and over again, at explainign that I had no interest in Nate's framework, in the sense that it wasn't the trigger to this entry.

I'm not really sure how to solve this problem. Repeating over and over again that it isn't about those 100 lines of code doesn't seem to get through, and the limits of my expressiveness in a foreign language have been hit. I declare conversation bankrupcy.

@John - Yes, that's doable, not sure it has much value, but as Krzysztof says, it adds in visibility so why not. Packages themselves can be shown in the PI, so that's something I've considered too.

@Troy - Absolutely. Binaries are just one export type, there's going to be more (documentation, static web content with js / css files come to mind first). It should be absolutely possible to have an aspnet-mvc export, a fubu-mvc one and an openrasta one if needed.

entry.title: @Troy: How you implement that would depend on what...
entry.content:
@Troy: How you implement that would depend on what you want to achieve.

When I talk about static content, I'm thinking of a package that any web framework can use. How they get the files in is dependent on the project: The package would probably be declared as anchored, which means you'd be able to link to it manually by going to /wraps/anchored/jquery and get whatever files are in there.

Alternatively, someone could build a VirtualPathProvider that would redirect all content in /web-static to a /lib folder, so that any asp.net site could use the content.

Or maybe for fx that understand OpenWrap (like openrasta), that linking will be done out of the box.

Or maybe we could change the project using the same injection process to add the files in a known location at the msbuild level.

Or maybe one could use post-install hooks to go and add stuff to a project file themselves, whenever something is installed.


There's many ways to achieve the same thing, and at this stage I don't have the resources to be prescriptive about it, I hope and expect the community to take ownership.

The only thing I would point you to is Reflexil. Malware that makes it easy to push your changes into DLLs. http://sebastien.lebreton.free.fr/reflexil/

entry.title:
Actually, no, it certainly doesn't.
You have ...
entry.content:
Actually, no, it certainly doesn't.

You have write access to the binaries. You can simply rewrite the exe. Or strip all the strong-name signatures and rewrite the assemblies. But at that stage, you're already running code, why go through the trouble? Just execute whatever code you want. I just don't see an attack vector that somehow would be prevented by strong-named assemblies. I don't see the vector of attack as being valid.

It doesn't provide for verifying who signed the strongly-named assembly either, as all keys are self-generated, and don't contain any author info.

THe only thing that sn ensures is that your code, provided it is not rewritten by any one, doesn't accidently load an assembly it didn't know about, so it prevents spoofing. But if you have write access to the app loading the assembly, you can already rewrite the whole thing...

There will be package signature in OpenWrap, where an author can sign their package, which will be verified at install-time. Then it's easy to verify that the assemblies come from the package.

entry.title: If executing code is on the box, your system is al...
entry.content:
If executing code is on the box, your system is already compromised. Signatures and strong names are irrelevant at that point, I agree.

I was thinking more along the lines of malicious code attempting to piggy back off an assembly. The assembly would be altered and therefore wouldn't execute.

Assemblies that aren't strong named/signed pose the risk of executing code that latched on during transit. No?

Well I think the point people are trying to make about signing is that:

- if you sign an assembly, and I trust you...
- and I don't trust Bob...
- and Bob sends me the assembly which was signed by you...
- then I can happily use that assembly because I know Bob couldn't have altered it...

Anyway not really something I have ever worried about, and I it's think a concern which is orthogonal to versioning and package management.

Agree with all your points - GAC is almost as evil as COM, and policy redirects are the work of the devil. This is stuff should be reserved for legacy scenarios only.
